title: How to Improve Screen Reader Support in Firefox?
content:
I’ve been using Firefox with a screen reader, and while it works for most basic browsing, I’ve noticed some issues with certain sites. For example, form fields aren’t always announced properly, and sometimes navigation landmarks are skipped. When I test the same pages in Chrome, the experience feels smoother.

I’d like to keep using Firefox, so I’m wondering — is there something I can adjust in my settings to improve screen reader support? Or is this more of a compatibility issue that needs to be reported as a bug?

If others here use screen readers with Firefox, I’d love to know what has worked for you. Are there specific add-ons, preferences, or troubleshooting steps that make accessibility better?

Thanks in advance for any guidance.

title: Low performance of NativeMessaging API in Firefox compared to Chromium (dozens of times slower)
content:
Description: We have encountered a significant performance issue with NativeMessaging API in Firefox when an extension communicates with a native application.

In scenarios where many objects must be enumerated (e.g., ~458 certificates), Firefox is dozens of times slower than Chromium-based browsers.

Environment:

Firefox (latest stable, reproduced in 2025)

Windows 11 x64

Same machine and same native plugin tested in Chrome, Edge, Yandex Browser

Steps to Reproduce:

Create a WebExtension that communicates with a native application via NativeMessaging.

Perform enumeration of a large number of objects (≈ 450–500).

Measure execution time in Firefox vs Chromium.

Actual results:

Firefox: enumeration of 458 objects takes ~2 min 30 sec

Chromium/Edge/Yandex Browser: enumeration of the same 458 objects takes ~5 sec

Additional tests: Round-trip time (RTT) for a single message:

Firefox: ~73.7 ms

Chromium: ~0.3 ms

Because the extension and the plugin exchange a large number of messages, this performance gap becomes critical.

Expected results: NativeMessaging API in Firefox should perform at a level comparable to Chromium browsers, so that extensions relying on heavy message exchange remain usable.

References: Bug 1288912 – Native messaging performance is extremely poor

Although this bug is marked as resolved, performance testing still shows a major discrepancy in the current versions of Firefox.

Question: Is there any ongoing work or plan to optimize the implementation of NativeMessaging API in Firefox to address this performance issue?
creator: artemvizgalin

title: Exploring Global Cuisines: Share Your Favorite Dishes
content:
Hello, fellow food enthusiasts!

As a passionate traveler and food lover, I've had the pleasure of tasting dishes from various corners of the world. From the spicy curries of India to the delicate sushi of Japan, each meal tells a unique story.

One of my recent discoveries is a delightful dish from Sweden. It's a hearty and flavorful meal that's perfect for the colder months. If you're interested in exploring more Swedish dishes, you might want to check out the max meny, which offers a comprehensive list of traditional recipes.

I'm curious to hear about your favorite dishes from around the world. What local specialties do you recommend? Let's share and inspire each other's culinary adventures!

Looking forward to your responses!

title: 关于火狐使用操作系统所设置的dns的逻辑
content:
Firefox Support Team, Hello I am a Firefox user in mainland China. I'm experiencing slow webpage opening (all webpages) with Firefox, and the problem persists after disabling the doh setting on Firefox as described on Firefox support. So I tried to change the doh settings on the OS (my OS is Windows 11, which supports doh settings on the OS), when I tried to use only the doh provider (Alidns) in mainland China, Firefox could open web pages very fast, but after I added the doh provider Opendns) outside of mainland China. Firefox becomes very slow in loading web pages. This problem only occurs in Firefox, not in chrome or edge (I currently use both Alidns and Opendns, Alidns as first choice and Opendns as backup).

So I would like to ask if Firefox has a logic that determines the priority of dns usage, prioritizing one of the dns providers when there are more than one at the same time. If so, can I change this logic. Because using dns services from other regions in mainland China will encounter problems such as very high network latency, packet loss, etc., I set up different regional dns providers at the same time as a backup, and I mainly use the mainland China dns provider.

My temporary solution for now is to actively enable doh service on Firefox and customize Alidns as the service provider. This gets Firefox working, but I think it adds complexity. Best regards, someone

The above is machine translation, the original Chinese text is as follows: 火狐支持团队，你好 我是中国大陆的火狐浏览器用户。我在使用火狐浏览器时遇到了网页打开缓慢的问题（所有网页），根据火狐支持上的描述关闭火狐上的doh设置后问题依旧。于是我尝试更改了操作系统上的doh设置（我的操作系统是Windows11，支持在操作系统上设置doh），当我尝试仅使用中国大陆的doh提供商（alidns）时，火狐可以很快的打开网页，但我加入中国大陆之外的doh提供商（opendns）后。火狐加载网页就会变得非常慢。这个问题仅在火狐浏览器出现，在chrome和edge上不会出现（我当前同时使用alidns和opendns，alidns作为首选，opendns作为备用）。

所以我想询问火狐浏览器是否有判断dns使用优先级的逻辑，在同时有多个dns提供商时优先使用其中某一个。如果有，我能否更改这个逻辑。因为在中国大陆使用其他地区的dns服务会遇到网络延迟很高、丢包等问题，我同时设置不同地区的dns提供商是为了备用，主要使用的是中国大陆的dns提供商。

目前我的临时解决办法是主动开启火狐上的doh服务，并自定义alidns为服务提供商。这样能使火狐正常工作，但我认为这样增加了复杂性。 谨致问候, someone
